exam_papers.title: 2023年12月大学英语四级考试真题（一）
exam_papers.description: 2023年12月大学英语四级考试真题（第一套），包含写作、听力、阅读理解和翻译四个部分

exam_sections.directions: Suppose the university newspaper is inviting submissions from the students for its coming edition on a campus event that has impressed them most. You are now to write an essay for submission. You will have 30 minutes to write the essay. You should write at least 120 words but no more than 180 words.

In this section, you will hear three news reports. At the end of each news report, you will hear two or three questions. Both the news report and the questions will be spoken only once. After you hear a question, you must choose the best answer from the four choices marked A), B), C) and D). Then mark the corresponding letter on Answer Sheet 1 with a single line through the centre.

In this section, you will hear two long conversations. At the end of each conversation, you will hear four questions. Both the conversation and the questions will be spoken only once. After you hear a question, you must choose the best answer from the four choices marked A), B), C) and D). Then mark the corresponding letter on Answer Sheet 1 with a single line through the centre.

In this section, you will hear three passages. At the end of each passage, you will hear three or four questions. Both the passage and the questions will be spoken only once. After you hear a question, you must choose the best answer from the four choices marked A), B), C) and D). Then mark the corresponding letter on Answer Sheet 1 with a single line through the centre.

In this section, there is a passage with ten blanks. You are required to select one word for each blank from a list of choices given in a word bank following the passage. Read the passage through carefully before making your choices. Each choice in the bank is identified by a letter. Please mark the corresponding letter for each item on Answer Sheet 2 with a single line through the centre. You may not use any of the words in the bank more than once.
exam_sections.passage_content:
Exercising for just 10 minutes a week is linked to a longer life, according to a new study published in The British Journal of Sports Medicine.

Several recent studies have found that even low-intensity exercise, done for a short amount of time, can have a meaningful impact on health. Still, the idea that exercising for just 10 minutes a week may be enough to increase your lifespan is novel. It's also somewhat controversial, since the federal physical activity guidelines recommend getting at least 75 minutes of vigorous exercise or 150 minutes of moderate exercise each week.

The study was based on data from more than 88,000 U.S. adults who participated in the National Health Interview Survey between 1997 and 2008.

Contrary to some research that has found an upper limit to the amount of exercise that is healthy, the researchers found that there was seemingly no limit to the longevity (长寿) benefits of exercise. Even the small group of people who got 10 times the amount of exercise recommended by the federal government had a 46% lower risk of death than the least active group.

Still, observational studies like this one cannot prove cause and effect; they can only find patterns. The researchers also were not able to adjust for certain lifestyle factors that could affect lifespan, including dietary habits and changes in physical activity over time. Despite these limitations, the study's results are yet another indication of the power of physical activity, even in small amounts.

exam_sections.directions: In this section, you are going to read a passage with ten statements attached to it. Each statement contains information given in one of the paragraphs. Identify the paragraph from which the information is derived. You may choose a paragraph more than once. Each paragraph is marked with a letter. Answer the questions by marking the corresponding letter on Answer Sheet 2.
exam_sections.passage_content:
A. Earlier this year, scientists warned that one in six animal species could go extinct (灭绝的) due to climate change. Could the same thing happen to our crops and other foodstuffs too?

B. It's clear that farmers in many parts of the world are going to find things harder in the coming decades. Last week, BBC Future explored one scientist's efforts to help crops cope with the increased probability of droughts. By using the genes from resurrection (复活) plants, Jill Farrant of the University of Cape Town is exploring whether she can design crops to survive for much longer periods without water.

C. But if we can't find ways to protect other foods, will they survive climate change? Fortunately, there is some good news on this front. Despite alarmist headlines about "foods that are going extinct," there is no evidence that major food types like beans, chocolate, wine, corn or wheat will cease to exist.

D. But that doesn't mean it's all good news for future food. We will probably have to change where we grow certain crops, as some regions get too hot. The disadvantage, obviously, is that local farmers will suffer under this situation. And some people may struggle to get the same access to certain foods. "Even if overall food production may be unaffected, food security can still be impacted," says Margaret Walsh, a scientist at the US Department of Agriculture's Climate Change Program Office. In other words, even if a certain food is still grown on some corner of the Earth, it doesn't mean that everyone will continue to have the same degree of access as today.

E. Overall, the yields of many foods, from staples to life-enhancing extras such as coffee and chocolate, will likely be impacted by climate change too. How those decreases will be felt will depend on the degree of warming and the crop in question, but in general, "anything over about 30°C is very bad for crops," says Wolfram Schlenker, an associate professor of international and public affairs at Columbia University. For example, statistical studies that he and a colleague built of corn and soybean (大豆) production in the US show a steep decline after crossing the 30°C temperature threshold (临界点).

F. In the US—the world's largest producer of corn and soybeans—farms can move north to some degree, Schlenker says. But eventually, yields will likely suffer because the soil north of Iowa declines in quality—a legacy of glacial (冰川的) expansion. Other studies, including studies of wheat in India and corn in Africa, also found that there is a threshold above which yields sharply decline: crops can adapt and move, but only to a point. "What's common to all studies is the finding that extreme heat is damaging to crop growth, although exact cutoffs vary by crop," Schlenker says. "If predictions for the end of the century are true, though, I think a lot of agricultural areas in the US will see significant hits."

G. Under current conditions, about 4% of the world's croplands experience drought in any given year, but by the end of the century those conditions are forecasted to jump to about 18% per year. Some studies indicate that horticulture crops—generally, everything besides staples—may be impacted most severely, largely because they tend to be confined to a smaller geographic area. Researcher Andrew Jarvis and his colleagues found that 80% of coffee-growing zones in Central America and Brazil could become unsuitable by 2050, for example, while climate change will likely have "great impacts" on cocoa (可可粉) production in West Africa. "High quality chocolate will be less available in the future, and if you want it, you'll have to pay a lot more for it," Jarvis says.

H. This means that, for those who can afford it, some foods will simply cost them more in the future. But for poorer people, those same price jumps will likely cause certain foods to go extinct from their diets. "The more you reduce, the shorter the supply, and the higher the price will jump," Schlenker says.

I. Another potential climate change-induced problem is our dependence on commodity crops—wheat, soybeans, corn and rice—which currently provide humanity with 75% of its calories, either directly or indirectly through the animals we raise on those crops. Jarvis and his colleagues also found that, over the past five decades, the world has seen an increasing standardisation of diets; the foods we eat globally today are 36% more similar than they were in 1961. While this can be good news for the world's poorest people who now consume more calories, protein and fat than in the past, homogeneity (同一性) and over-dependence on a handful of staples leaves us vulnerable to threats such as drought, disease and pests—all of which are predicted to worsen in many parts of the world as a result of climate change.

J. There are ways we could soften the coming blow to the global food supply, however. Like Farrant's work with resurrection crops, a number of companies, organisations and researchers are aiming to create drought- and temperature-resistant crops through genetic engineering and conventional breeding. For now, the jury is still out as to how successful those endeavours will be. "The people at Monsanto who I've talked to are much more optimistic that they'll be able to engineer heat-tolerant crops," Schlenker says. "On the other hand, scientists at the USDA who I've spoken with are much more cautious."

K. Until genetic engineering comes to fruition, other strategies might also help in some places, including applying more fertiliser, implementing better irrigation, using machinery that gets crops out of the field faster or installing storage facilities to delay spoilage. "Many places could benefit a great deal just by using technologies that already exist," Walsh says. "General farm management can go a long way toward easing changes."

L. Finally, diversifying our diet away from heat-sensitive wheat, corn, rice and other crops could also help. "We've seen profound changes in the last decades in what we eat largely as a result of international trade, and I think that trend toward more diversification will continue," Jarvis says. "Depending on a greater number of plant species creates a more vigorous and less risky food system—and one that provides a broader range of nutritional requirements."
exam_sections.passage_title: How Climate Change Will Affect What You Eat

exam_sections.directions: There are 2 passages in this section. Each passage is followed by some questions or unfinished statements. For each of them there are four choices marked A), B), C) and D). You should decide on the best choice and mark the corresponding letter on Answer Sheet 2 with a single line through the centre.
exam_sections.passage_content:
Passage One

One of my bad habits is saying "busy" when people ask me how I'm doing. Sometimes it's because I actually am busy, but other times it's because that's what I think I'm supposed to say. That's what important people say. That's what people who get promoted say. But working long hours doesn't drive better results. Never taking a vacation won't lead to a promotion. So why are we so proud to talk about how busy we are all the time?

In 2016, researchers from Columbia, Harvard, and Georgetown conducted a study to figure it out. They found busy people are perceived to be of high status, and interestingly, these status attributions are heavily influenced by our own beliefs about social mobility. In other words, the more we believe that one has the opportunity for success based on hard work, the more we tend to think that people who skip leisure and work all the time are of higher standing.

That's why we feel like we have to appear busy, and there's a real perception that if someone is knee-deep in meetings, emails, and stress, then they're probably a big deal. This culture of busyness is making it hard for employees to find work-life balance. According to a recent study, one in five highly engaged employees is at risk of burnout (精疲力竭).

Personally, I'm going to stop saying "busy" when people ask me how I am. It sounds self-righteous (自以为是的) and sets the wrong tone. Phrases like "I have limited access to email" and "I'll respond as soon as I get back" sound like you're being held against your will from working as opposed to making the most of your time off.

That's why we recently launched the Out of Office Email Generator, a free tool you can use before your next long weekend or trip. You can share loud and proud that you won't be checking email until you're back. Managers need to think twice about emailing their teams on the weekend and talking about how busy they are. Leaders should take time off themselves and encourage employees to do the same.

Passage Two

Female employees consistently pay lower airfares than men do for the same flights because they tend to book earlier.

We compared the airfare paid by employees in the same position within a company for the same class of travel and used a common statistical technique to account for other factors that might affect differences in airfares. We found that women paid on average $18 less per ticket than their male colleagues. Further investigation allowed us to conclude that this gap is largely explained by the fact that women tended to book earlier than men, 1.8 days on average.

We wanted to determine what was causing these gender differences in booking business trips so we tested a variety of possible explanations, such as women choosing to plan ahead or male frequent travelers being inclined to book late. None of these explained away the gender gap, so we applied data collected from surveys that express consumer preferences that play a central role in economic decisions, such as patience and risk avoidance.

We found that only the concept of "negative reciprocity"—in which an employee who feels unfairly treated engages in negative behaviors, such as spending their company's money less carefully—explains these differences. The surveys showed men tend to exhibit more of these negative behaviors than women. This isn't to say that all men engage in these behaviors—or that booking relatively late is a sign of abnormal behavior. It only means that the gender gap disappears when we plug in the negative reciprocity variable.

Prior research on negative reciprocity among workers found that it can result in lower employee motivation, business performance and workplace morale (士气) and culture.

Our results show another way these negative behaviors can manifest themselves, like in airline bookings, and add to evidence that women are less likely to engage in them.

Companies spend significant sums of money on business travel. While that $18 difference per ticket may seem small, it adds up. Our analysis suggests early booking by women can translate into savings of $1 million a year for a large multinational company with 20,000 regular travelers.

exam_sections.directions: For this part, you are allowed 30 minutes to translate a passage from Chinese into English. You should write your answer on Answer Sheet 2.
exam_sections.translation_content: 中国政府十分重视人民的健康饮食（diet）。通过大力提倡健康饮食，人们对合理营养增进健康的重要性有了更加深刻的认识。"吃得安全、吃得营养、吃得健康"是人民对美好生活的基本需要，是提升人民幸福感的必然要求，也为食品产业的发展提供了新机遇。目前，各级政府都在采取多种举措确保人民饮食健康，推进健康中国的建设。
exam_sections.translation_requirements: 请将以下中文段落准确翻译成英文，注意语法正确和表达流畅

exam_questions.question_text: Write an essay for the university newspaper about a campus event that has impressed you most.
exam_questions.analysis: 写作题目，需要学生为校报写一篇关于印象最深刻的校园活动的文章
exam_questions.explanation: 考查学生的记叙文写作能力，包括事件描述、细节描写和个人感受表达

exam_questions.question_text: What do we learn about close friends from the news report?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Their brains work in harmony.", "B) They are generally the same age.", "C) Their interests are quite similar.", "D) They have the same ethnic background."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。新闻中提到，研究发现亲密朋友的大脑活动模式很相似，因此答案为A)。
exam_questions.explanation: 新闻中提到：'Research shows that close friends have similar brain activity patterns.'

exam_questions.question_text: What does the news report say about friendship?
exam_questions.options: ["A) It can be touching.", "B) It is hard to predict.", "C) It can work both ways.", "D) It resembles family ties."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。新闻中提到，友谊类似于家庭纽带，因此答案为D)。
exam_questions.explanation: 新闻中提到：'Friendship is similar to family ties in many ways.'

exam_questions.question_text: Why did the two men take DNA tests?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Search for their half-brothers.", "B) Identify their biological fathers.", "C) Find out more about their ancestry.", "D) See whether they are actually related."]
exam_questions.analysis: 目的原因题。新闻中提到，两人进行DNA测试是为了确认他们是否有血缘关系，因此答案为D)。
exam_questions.explanation: 新闻中提到：'They took DNA tests to confirm if they were biologically related.'

exam_questions.question_text: What do we learn about the two men from the news report?
exam_questions.options: ["A) They were both given up for adoption.", "B) They were born to the same mother.", "C) They flew 737 airplanes as pilots.", "D) They were both 60 years of age."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。新闻中提到，两人都是737飞机的飞行员，因此答案为C)。
exam_questions.explanation: 新闻中提到：'Both men worked as pilots flying 737 airplanes.'

exam_questions.question_text: What made the man start the beach cleanup?
exam_questions.options: ["A) One of his friends was caught littering.", "B) Other tourists refused to join in the cleanup.", "C) The beautiful beach was spoiled with lots of trash.", "D) The kilometer-long beach was practically deserted."]
exam_questions.analysis: 目的原因题。新闻中提到，男子看到美丽的海滩被垃圾破坏，于是开始清理，因此答案为C)。
exam_questions.explanation: 新闻中提到：'He was upset to see the beautiful beach spoiled with trash.'

exam_questions.question_text: Who joined the man in the beach cleanup?
exam_questions.options: ["A) A passerby.", "B) A local woman.", "C) The beach authorities.", "D) One of the five tourists."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。新闻中提到，一名当地妇女加入了海滩清理工作，因此答案为B)。
exam_questions.explanation: 新闻中提到：'A local woman saw him and decided to join the cleanup effort.'

exam_questions.question_text: What does the news report say about the beach cleanup?
exam_questions.options: ["A) The tourists' good deed was not noticed by the locals.", "B) Some natives were selling poor-quality food to tourists.", "C) The number of tourists to the beach is on a steady decline.", "D) It was tourists not natives who were cleaning up the beach."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。新闻中提到，是游客而不是当地人在清理海滩，因此答案为D)。
exam_questions.explanation: 新闻中提到：'It was tourists, not locals, who were cleaning up the beach.'

exam_questions.question_text: Why can't the man go hiking this weekend?
exam_questions.options: ["A) He has to play football with workmates.", "B) He has got some books to read.", "C) He is going to visit a friend.", "D) He is physically unfit for it."]
exam_questions.analysis: 目的原因题。对话中男士提到他脚踝肿胀，身体状况不适合徒步，因此答案为D)。
exam_questions.explanation: 对话中提到：'My ankle is swollen and I'm not in good shape for hiking.'

exam_questions.question_text: Why does the woman want to go to the zoo?
exam_questions.options: ["A) To teach kids about animal protection.", "B) To learn how popular zoos could be.", "C) To see some rare animals in cages.", "D) To give her little nephew a treat."]
exam_questions.analysis: 目的原因题。对话中女士提到要带小侄子去动物园玩，因此答案为D)。
exam_questions.explanation: 对话中提到：'I promised to take my little nephew to the zoo as a treat.'

exam_questions.question_text: What do we learn about the man from the conversation?
exam_questions.options: ["A) He enjoys excellent health.", "B) He is keen on extreme sports.", "C) He coaches tennis players every week.", "D) He spends most of his time in the gym."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。对话中男士提到他每周都指导网球运动员，因此答案为C)。
exam_questions.explanation: 对话中提到：'I coach tennis players every week as part of my job.'

exam_questions.question_text: What will the man do this weekend?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Tending to his swollen ankle.", "B) Concentrating on reading.", "C) Writing three book reports.", "D) Planning Christmas celebrations."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。对话中男士提到他周末要专心读书，因此答案为B)。
exam_questions.explanation: 对话中提到：'I'll be concentrating on my reading this weekend.'

exam_questions.question_text: What does the man say about the book he is reading?
exam_questions.options: ["A) It is being debated by hundreds of retirees.", "B) It is attracting many people's attention.", "C) It partly records his own experience.", "D) It argues for postponing retirement."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。对话中男士提到这本书部分记录了他自己的经历，因此答案为C)。
exam_questions.explanation: 对话中提到：'The book partly records some of my own experiences.'

exam_questions.question_text: What is the book's advice on retirement planning?
exam_questions.options: ["A) One should foresee a financial crisis.", "B) One should trust financial planners' figures.", "C) One should have one million dollars to retire.", "D) One should start saving as early as possible."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。对话中提到书中的建议是尽早开始储蓄，因此答案为D)。
exam_questions.explanation: 对话中提到：'The book advises starting to save as early as possible.'

exam_questions.question_text: What does the man say about retirement?
exam_questions.options: ["A) It doesn't need to be permanent.", "B) It helps to reduce travel expenses.", "C) It is the way to quit a job one hates.", "D) It means the end of one's career."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。对话中男士提到退休不一定是永久性的，因此答案为A)。
exam_questions.explanation: 对话中提到：'Retirement doesn't have to be permanent.'

exam_questions.question_text: How can one ensure a comfortable retirement according to the book?
exam_questions.options: ["A) By keeping close contact with one's employers.", "B) By investing half of one's monthly income.", "C) By following the counsel of financial planners.", "D) By making wise investment decisions early."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。对话中提到书中建议尽早做出明智的投资决策，因此答案为D)。
exam_questions.explanation: 对话中提到：'The book suggests making wise investment decisions early.'

exam_questions.question_text: What did the researchers find about people's food choices?
exam_questions.options: ["A) They tended to be easily anticipated by those belonging to their own race.", "B) They tended to be arbitrarily judged by individuals of opposing groups.", "C) They were readily shared among members of the same social or racial group.", "D) They were influenced by the presence of someone from an outsider group."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。短文中提到，人们的食物选择受到外来群体成员在场的影响，因此答案为D)。
exam_questions.explanation: 短文中提到：'People's food choices were influenced when someone from an outsider group was present.'

exam_questions.question_text: When did participants make healthier food choices?
exam_questions.options: ["A) When they tried to make a positive impression on the researchers.", "B) When an unknown student from another university was present.", "C) When an experimenter from the research team took notice.", "D) When they were offered both candy and fruit as a snack."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。短文中提到，当有其他大学的陌生学生在场时，参与者会选择更健康的食物，因此答案为B)。
exam_questions.explanation: 短文中提到：'Participants chose healthier food when an unknown student from another university was present.'

exam_questions.question_text: How can a company promote healthy eating?
exam_questions.options: ["A) By advertising its social benefits.", "B) By teaching consumers diet strategies.", "C) By supporting struggling consumers.", "D) By maintaining its positive image."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。短文中提到，公司可以通过宣传健康饮食的社会效益来推广健康饮食，因此答案为A)。
exam_questions.explanation: 短文中提到：'Companies can promote healthy eating by advertising its social benefits.'

exam_questions.question_text: What is the passage mainly about?
exam_questions.options: ["A) The academic and learning issues struggling students encounter.", "B) The risk students face due to a history of mental health problems.", "C) The effect of interacting with therapy dogs on students under pressure.", "D) The work universities are doing to help students succeed academically."]
exam_questions.analysis: 主旨大意题。短文主要讨论了与治疗犬互动对压力下学生的影响，因此答案为C)。
exam_questions.explanation: 短文主要围绕治疗犬对学生心理压力的缓解作用展开讨论。

exam_questions.question_text: What can therapy dogs help improve in students?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Their communicative skills.", "B) Their executive functioning.", "C) Their academic networking.", "D) Their leadership capacities."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。短文中提到，治疗犬可以帮助改善学生的执行功能，因此答案为B)。
exam_questions.explanation: 短文中提到：'Therapy dogs can help improve students' executive functioning.'

exam_questions.question_text: What effect do therapy dogs have on students with mental issues?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Rid students of their anxiety.", "B) Add to some students' stress.", "C) Contribute little to typical students' success.", "D) Help students with mental issues pull through."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。短文中提到，治疗犬能帮助有心理问题的学生渡过难关，因此答案为D)。
exam_questions.explanation: 短文中提到：'Therapy dogs help students with mental issues pull through difficult times.'

exam_questions.question_text: What is the key to success according to the passage?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Work hard and plan carefully.", "B) Attempt to succeed at any cost.", "C) Aim high and expect great results.", "D) Remain optimistic even in difficulty."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。短文中提到，即使在困难中保持乐观也是成功的关键，因此答案为D)。
exam_questions.explanation: 短文中提到：'Remaining optimistic even in difficulty is key to success.'

exam_questions.question_text: What should entrepreneurs do to achieve success?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Regarding failure as something inevitable.", "B) Trying out innovative marketing strategies.", "C) Venturing into sectors never explored before.", "D) Being willing to experiment with novel ideas."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。短文中提到，企业家应该愿意尝试新想法，因此答案为D)。
exam_questions.explanation: 短文中提到：'Entrepreneurs should be willing to experiment with novel ideas.'

exam_questions.question_text: What should we do after experiencing failure?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Expect future success so as to move forward.", "B) Learn from our failure and forge ahead.", "C) Distinguish between good and bad risks.", "D) Examine our strategies and find out weaknesses."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。短文中提到，我们应该从失败中学习并继续前进，因此答案为B)。
exam_questions.explanation: 短文中提到：'We should learn from failure and continue moving forward.'

exam_questions.question_text: What advantage does a new business have over established ones?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Fresher offers.", "B) Safer operation.", "C) More challenges.", "D) Less competition."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。短文中提到，新企业比老企业有更新的产品/服务，因此答案为A)。
exam_questions.explanation: 短文中提到：'New businesses have fresher offers compared to established ones.'

exam_questions.options: ["A) adjust", "B) alter", "C) approximately", "D) controversial", "E) coordinates", "F) impact", "G) limitations", "H) moderate", "I) participated", "J) patterns", "K) populated", "L) risk", "M) seemingly", "N) type", "O) upper"]
exam_questions.analysis: 名词辨析题。空格位于形容词meaningful之后，因此需要填入名词。句意：即使是低强度、短时间的运动也能对健康产生有意义的影响。故本题答案为F) impact。
exam_questions.explanation: impact表示影响，符合上下文关于运动对健康影响的讨论。

exam_questions.options: ["A) adjust", "B) alter", "C) approximately", "D) controversial", "E) coordinates", "F) impact", "G) limitations", "H) moderate", "I) participated", "J) patterns", "K) populated", "L) risk", "M) seemingly", "N) type", "O) upper"]
exam_questions.analysis: 形容词辨析题。空格位于系动词is和副词somewhat之后，因此需要填入形容词。句意：这个观点也有些争议，因为联邦体育活动指南建议每周至少进行75分钟剧烈运动或150分钟中等强度运动。故本题答案为D) controversial。
exam_questions.explanation: controversial表示有争议的，符合上下文关于运动时长建议的对比。

exam_questions.options: ["A) adjust", "B) alter", "C) approximately", "D) controversial", "E) coordinates", "F) impact", "G) limitations", "H) moderate", "I) participated", "J) patterns", "K) populated", "L) risk", "M) seemingly", "N) type", "O) upper"]
exam_questions.analysis: 形容词辨析题。空格位于名词exercise之前，因此需要填入形容词。句意：联邦指南建议每周进行150分钟中等强度运动。故本题答案为H) moderate。
exam_questions.explanation: moderate exercise表示中等强度运动，是常见的运动分类。

exam_questions.options: ["A) adjust", "B) alter", "C) approximately", "D) controversial", "E) coordinates", "F) impact", "G) limitations", "H) moderate", "I) participated", "J) patterns", "K) populated", "L) risk", "M) seemingly", "N) type", "O) upper"]
exam_questions.analysis: 动词辨析题。空格位于who引导的定语从句中，需要填入动词过去式。句意：参与全国健康访谈调查的88,000名美国成年人。故本题答案为I) participated。
exam_questions.explanation: participated in表示参与，符合调查研究的语境。

exam_questions.options: ["A) adjust", "B) alter", "C) approximately", "D) controversial", "E) coordinates", "F) impact", "G) limitations", "H) moderate", "I) participated", "J) patterns", "K) populated", "L) risk", "M) seemingly", "N) type", "O) upper"]
exam_questions.analysis: 形容词辨析题。空格位于不定冠词an之后，名词limit之前，因此需要填入形容词。句意：与一些研究发现运动量有上限的研究相反。故本题答案为O) upper。
exam_questions.explanation: upper limit表示上限，符合关于运动量限制的讨论。

exam_questions.options: ["A) adjust", "B) alter", "C) approximately", "D) controversial", "E) coordinates", "F) impact", "G) limitations", "H) moderate", "I) participated", "J) patterns", "K) populated", "L) risk", "M) seemingly", "N) type", "O) upper"]
exam_questions.analysis: 副词辨析题。空格位于was和no limit之间，因此需要填入副词。句意：研究人员发现运动对长寿的好处似乎没有限制。故本题答案为M) seemingly。
exam_questions.explanation: seemingly表示似乎、表面上，符合研究发现的表述方式。

exam_questions.options: ["A) adjust", "B) alter", "C) approximately", "D) controversial", "E) coordinates", "F) impact", "G) limitations", "H) moderate", "I) participated", "J) patterns", "K) populated", "L) risk", "M) seemingly", "N) type", "O) upper"]
exam_questions.analysis: 名词辨析题。空格位于形容词lower之后，介词of之前，因此需要填入名词。句意：死亡风险比最不活跃组低46%。故本题答案为L) risk。
exam_questions.explanation: risk of death表示死亡风险，是医学研究常用术语。

exam_questions.options: ["A) adjust", "B) alter", "C) approximately", "D) controversial", "E) coordinates", "F) impact", "G) limitations", "H) moderate", "I) participated", "J) patterns", "K) populated", "L) risk", "M) seemingly", "N) type", "O) upper"]
exam_questions.analysis: 名词辨析题。空格位于动词find之后，因此需要填入名词。句意：它们只能发现模式。故本题答案为J) patterns。
exam_questions.explanation: patterns表示模式、规律，符合观察性研究的特点。

exam_questions.options: ["A) adjust", "B) alter", "C) approximately", "D) controversial", "E) coordinates", "F) impact", "G) limitations", "H) moderate", "I) participated", "J) patterns", "K) populated", "L) risk", "M) seemingly", "N) type", "O) upper"]
exam_questions.analysis: 动词辨析题。空格位于were not able to之后，因此需要填入动词原形。句意：研究人员也无法调整某些可能影响寿命的生活方式因素。故本题答案为A) adjust。
exam_questions.explanation: adjust for表示调整、校正，是统计学常用术语。

exam_questions.options: ["A) adjust", "B) alter", "C) approximately", "D) controversial", "E) coordinates", "F) impact", "G) limitations", "H) moderate", "I) participated", "J) patterns", "K) populated", "L) risk", "M) seemingly", "N) type", "O) upper"]
exam_questions.analysis: 名词辨析题。空格位于指示代词these之后，因此需要填入名词。句意：尽管有这些限制，研究结果仍然表明了体育活动的作用。故本题答案为G) limitations。
exam_questions.explanation: limitations表示局限性，符合研究讨论的语境。

exam_questions.question_text: One consequence of climate change is that some people may not have adequate access to certain foods.
exam_questions.analysis: 同义转述题。定位句提到，即使某种食物仍在地球的某个角落种植，也不意味着每个人都能继续享有与今天相同程度的获取机会。题干中的some people may not have adequate access to certain foods是对定位句的同义转述，故答案为D)。
exam_questions.explanation: D段最后一句：'even if a certain food is still grown on some corner of the Earth, it doesn't mean that everyone will continue to have the same degree of access as today.'

exam_questions.question_text: People around the world are eating foods more similar than what they used to eat.
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。定位句提到，过去五十年来，世界饮食标准化程度不断提高；我们今天在全球食用的食物比1961年时相似度提高了36%。题干是对定位句的同义转述，故答案为I)。
exam_questions.explanation: I段第二句：'the foods we eat globally today are 36% more similar than they were in 1961.'

exam_questions.question_text: A recent news report talked about scientific efforts to help crops survive droughts through genetic engineering.
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。定位句提到，BBC Future上周探讨了一位科学家帮助作物应对干旱概率增加的努力。通过使用复活植物的基因，她正在探索是否能设计出在无水情况下存活更长时间的作物。题干是对定位句的概括，故答案为B)。
exam_questions.explanation: B段第二、三句：'Last week, BBC Future explored one scientist's efforts to help crops cope with the increased probability of droughts. By using the genes from resurrection plants...is exploring whether she can design crops to survive for much longer periods without water.'

exam_questions.question_text: It is predicted that climate change will affect the availability and price of quality chocolate.
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。定位句提到，未来高品质巧克力的供应将减少，如果想要，就得花更多钱购买。题干是对定位句的同义转述，故答案为G)。
exam_questions.explanation: G段最后一句：'High quality chocolate will be less available in the future, and if you want it, you'll have to pay a lot more for it.'

exam_questions.question_text: People wonder if certain crops and foodstuffs could disappear like some animal species due to climate change.
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。定位句提到，我们的作物和其他食物也会发生同样的情况吗？题干是对定位句的同义转述，故答案为A)。
exam_questions.explanation: A段最后一句：'Could the same thing happen to our crops and other foodstuffs too?'

exam_questions.question_text: Although farms in the US can move a bit northward, crop yields may decrease.
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。定位句提到，美国的农场可以在一定程度上向北迁移，但最终产量可能会受到影响。题干是对定位句的同义转述，故答案为F)。
exam_questions.explanation: F段第一、二句：'In the US—the world's largest producer of corn and soybeans—farms can move north to some degree. But eventually, yields will likely suffer...'

exam_questions.question_text: One possible solution to the food security problem is diversification of diet.
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。定位句提到，使我们的饮食多样化，远离对热敏感的小麦、玉米、水稻和其他作物，也会有所帮助。题干是对定位句的概括，故答案为L)。
exam_questions.explanation: L段第一句：'Finally, diversifying our diet away from heat-sensitive wheat, corn, rice and other crops could also help.'

exam_questions.question_text: It remains unsettled whether the global food supply problem can be solved by creating heat-tolerant crops through genetic engineering.
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。定位句提到，目前尚不清楚这些努力会有多成功。题干是对定位句的同义转述，故答案为J)。
exam_questions.explanation: J段第三句：'For now, the jury is still out as to how successful those endeavours will be.'

exam_questions.question_text: Poor people may have to give up eating certain foods because of their high prices.
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。定位句提到，对于穷人来说，同样的价格上涨可能会导致某些食物从他们的饮食中消失。题干是对定位句的同义转述，故答案为H)。
exam_questions.explanation: H段第二句：'But for poorer people, those same price jumps will likely cause certain foods to go extinct from their diets.'

exam_questions.question_text: A number of existing farming technologies could be used to reduce the negative effect of climate change on food production.
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。定位句提到，许多地方只需使用现有技术就能受益匪浅。题干是对定位句的概括，故答案为K)。
exam_questions.explanation: K段最后两句：'Many places could benefit a great deal just by using technologies that already exist. General farm management can go a long way toward easing changes.'

exam_questions.question_text: What is a reason for the author to be in the habit of saying "busy" when asked how he is doing?
exam_questions.options: ["A) He just follows successful people's example.", "B) He is actually proud to be fully occupied.", "C) He thinks everyone should be devoted to work.", "D) He believes busyness ensures accomplishments."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。定位句指出，作者有时说"忙"是因为他认为这是重要人物和被提拔的人会说的话。由此可见，作者是仿效成功人士的例子，故答案为A)。
exam_questions.explanation: 第一段第三、四句：'Sometimes it's because I actually am busy, but other times it's because that's what I think I'm supposed to say. That's what important people say. That's what people who get promoted say.'

exam_questions.question_text: Why do we tend to think that busy people are of high status?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Our status can be attributed to our social mobility.", "B) We hold the belief that hard work leads to success.", "C) Our own opportunity for success never comes easily.", "D) We find few people of high status have time for leisure."]
exam_questions.analysis: 目的原因题。定位句指出，我们越相信一个人有机会通过努力工作获得成功，就越倾向于认为那些跳过休闲、一直工作的人地位更高。由此可见，我们认为忙碌的人地位高是因为我们相信努力工作的价值，故答案为B)。
exam_questions.explanation: 第二段最后一句：'the more we believe that one has the opportunity for success based on hard work, the more we tend to think that people who skip leisure and work all the time are of higher standing.'

exam_questions.question_text: What do we learn about the culture of busyness from a recent study?
exam_questions.options: ["A) It places employees in endless meetings, emails and stress.", "B) It compels some 20% of employees to appear always busy.", "C) It distorts many employees' belief of what a satisfying life is.", "D) It does much harm to many busy employees' well-being."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。定位句指出，这种忙碌文化使得员工很难找到工作与生活的平衡，五分之一的敬业员工面临精疲力竭的风险。由此可见，忙碌文化对员工的健康有害，故答案为D)。
exam_questions.explanation: 第三段最后两句：'This culture of busyness is making it hard for employees to find work-life balance. According to a recent study, one in five highly engaged employees is at risk of burnout.'

exam_questions.question_text: What do such utterances as "I have limited access to email" sound like according to the author?
exam_questions.options: ["A) One is too busy to check all emails in time.", "B) One is opposed to the prevailing work culture.", "C) One is forced by circumstances to stop working.", "D) One is simply enjoying their time off work."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。定位句指出，像"我收发邮件有限"这样的说法听起来像是被迫停止工作，而不是在充分利用休息时间。由此可见，作者认为这种说法听起来像是被迫停止工作，故答案为C)。
exam_questions.explanation: 第四段最后一句：'Phrases like "I have limited access to email" and "I'll respond as soon as I get back" sound like you're being held against your will from working as opposed to making the most of your time off.'

exam_questions.question_text: Why did the author and his colleagues launch the Out of Office Email Generator?
exam_questions.options: ["A) To enable busy employees to spend less time checking emails.", "B) To ensure employees as well as employers truly have time off.", "C) To stop managers from talking about how busy their teams usually are.", "D) To encourage both employers and employees to answer emails promptly."]
exam_questions.analysis: 目的原因题。定位段提到，作者团队推出这个工具是为了让员工能够自豪地宣布在休假期间不查看邮件，经理们需要在周末给团队发邮件前三思，领导者应该自己休假并鼓励员工也这样做。由此可见，目的是确保员工和雇主都能真正休息，故答案为B)。
exam_questions.explanation: 最后一段：'You can share loud and proud that you won't be checking email until you're back. Managers need to think twice about emailing their teams on the weekend and talking about how busy they are. Leaders should take time off themselves and encourage employees to do the same.'

exam_questions.question_text: What did the author's team conclude about the gender difference in airfares from their further investigation?
exam_questions.options: ["A) It is largely attributed to women booking earlier than men.", "B) It is largely explained by women's choosing cheaper flights.", "C) It is mainly accounted for by male employees' readiness to pay more.", "D) It is due to the fact that women care more about their company's money."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。定位句指出，进一步调查使他们得出结论，这种差距很大程度上是因为女性倾向于比男性更早预订机票。由此可见，性别差异主要归因于女性预订更早，故答案为A)。
exam_questions.explanation: 第二段最后一句：'Further investigation allowed us to conclude that this gap is largely explained by the fact that women tended to book earlier than men, 1.8 days on average.'

exam_questions.question_text: What did the researchers want to determine by testing a variety of possible explanations?
exam_questions.options: ["A) What made male frequent travelers book air tickets late.", "B) What caused women to plan ahead in booking business trips.", "C) What motivated women to book cheaper flights.", "D) What accounted for the gender gap in airfares."]
exam_questions.analysis: 目的原因题。定位句指出，研究人员想确定造成商务旅行预订中性别差异的原因。由此可见，他们测试各种可能解释的目的是找出性别差距的原因，故答案为D)。
exam_questions.explanation: 第三段第一句：'We wanted to determine what was causing these gender differences in booking business trips so we tested a variety of possible explanations.'

exam_questions.question_text: What happened when the negative reciprocity variable was taken into account?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Both men and women were found to engage in negative behaviors.", "B) Neither men nor women viewed booking late as a bad behavior.", "C) The gender difference in airfare expenses no longer existed.", "D) The gender gap tended to narrow to a significant degree."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。定位句指出，当我们加入负互惠变量时，性别差距就消失了。由此可见，考虑负互惠变量后，性别差异不再存在，故答案为C)。
exam_questions.explanation: 第四段最后一句：'It only means that the gender gap disappears when we plug in the negative reciprocity variable.'

exam_questions.question_text: What did prior research on negative reciprocity among workers find?
exam_questions.options: ["A) It can do more harm to the workplace than to employees.", "B) It contributes to the male-female divide in the workplace.", "C) It proves to be counterproductive in a number of ways.", "D) It can result in increasing labor-management conflicts."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。定位句指出，先前关于员工负互惠的研究发现，它会导致员工积极性、企业绩效和工作场所士气和文化的降低。由此可见，负互惠在多个方面适得其反，故答案为C)。
exam_questions.explanation: 第五段：'Prior research on negative reciprocity among workers found that it can result in lower employee motivation, business performance and workplace morale and culture.'

exam_questions.question_text: What does the author emphasize about their analysis in the last paragraph?
exam_questions.options: ["A) It can help companies increase their savings significantly.", "B) It can duly contribute to companies' business performance.", "C) It can translate women's booking practice into men's behavior.", "D) It can enhance large multinational companies' competitiveness."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。定位段指出，每张机票18美元的差异看似很小，但会累积起来。对于拥有2万名经常出差员工的大型跨国公司来说，女性提前预订可以转化为每年100万美元的节省。由此可见，作者强调他们的分析可以帮助公司显著增加储蓄，故答案为A)。
exam_questions.explanation: 最后一段：'While that $18 difference per ticket may seem small, it adds up. Our analysis suggests early booking by women can translate into savings of $1 million a year for a large multinational company with 20,000 regular travelers.'

exam_questions.question_text: Translate the Chinese passage into English.
exam_questions.analysis: 翻译题目，需要学生将中文段落准确翻译成英文，注意语法、词汇和句式结构的正确性
exam_questions.explanation: 考查学生的汉译英能力，包括词汇选择、语法结构、句式转换和语言表达的准确性
